intro: Anagallis linifolia, commonly known as the thread-leaved willow herb, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its slender, linear leaves and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows, woodlands, and along stream banks. It is an annual or biennial species, reaching heights of up to 60 centimeters. Its flowers attract various pollinators, including bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
